data.text: On occasion it is necessary to provide greater levels of non-clinical supervision to ensure the safety of patients and those around them. The risk may arise for many reasons including suicide, self-harm or behaviours which may present a risk to the patient or others. This policy aims to provide a safe, lawful and supportive framework for the assessment, provision and de-escalation of increased levels of non-clinical observation.
The purpose of this document is to ensure that patients aged 16 and over being treated in adult inpatient areas and requiring increased levels of non-clinical supervision:
Are assessed and managed lawfully with respect to the Mental Capacity Act, Deprivation of Liberty and Safeguarding requirements
Receive the least restrictive level of observation necessary to maintain their safety and that of those around them for the least possible time
Are regularly reassessed for their level of observation requirements
Receive supervision which is supportive and personally tailored to the individual needs of the patient
This policy does not apply to those being detained under the Mental Health Act (1983)
This policy does not cover patients requiring frequent or continuous clinical observations or interventions

table_items.text: The increased monitoring of patients who lack capacity and are under a Deprivation of Liberty to enable them to be closely supervised to prevent injury to themselves or others.

An assessment to determine if a patient has the metal capacity to make a decision regarding their management and care. It tests whether a patient is able to understand, retain, weigh up the information and communicate their decision

The Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards is the procedure prescribed in law when it is necessary to deprive of their liberty a resident or patient who lacks capacity to consent to their care and treatment in order to keep them safe from harm

Standard “Care rounding” which is used to ensure patients whereabouts and comfort. This if for patients who have capacity and would be free to leave the ward area if they chose to do so. It may also be suitable for patients lacking capacity but who are not showing behaviours which present risk of harm to themselves or others

More frequent, intermittent non-clinical supervision where the patient is left unattended at times. For example, 15-30 minute checks. The time intervals will vary on the needs of the patient and may be randomised so that patients do not predict the visit and alter behaviours accordingly
The patient is to be within eyesight at all times and is not left unsupervised

The patient is within arm's reach at all times. This is for extreme circumstances where the patient's behaviours are likely to need physical intervention or restraint to prevent injury to self or others

This refers to having a member of staff present within a bay at all times whilst not assigned to the observation of an identified individual. This may be used to cohort a number of vulnerable patients to monitor their behaviours and assess levels of risk where it is not clear how patients may behave. Patients with capacity within the Bay should be aware that this is taking place and given to opportunity to be relocated if they are not in agreement.

data.text: The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, the post holder is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available.

Chief Nursing Officer, Directors of Nursing – responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate this policy in all adult clinical areas. This includes ensuring that the Trust provides / supports the training required for staff to undertake the task.
Deputy Director of Nursing and Midwifery and Clinical Directors will ensure that all staff within their Division are aware of and comply with this policy.

Matrons, Clinical Site Managers, Hospital out of Hours (HOOH) or other Decision Makers with responsibility for staffing the provision of Enhanced Supervision which cannot be covered within existing ward staffing:

Decision makers with regard to resourcing staffing required to provide Enhanced Supervision must act in accordance with the policy and with the Enhanced Supervision Flow Chart (see appendix). In instances where staff cannot be provided to meet the level of supervision required the decision maker must work with the Nurse in Charge to agree suitable mitigation.

The Nurse in charge is responsible for ensuring patients requiring enhanced Supervision have completed Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberties assessments in place, or ensure that the supervision is in the patients best interest if there is an immediate risk. They will agree the level of supervision required and refer to the Enhanced Supervision Flow chart for implementation (See appendix)
The Nurse in charge will ensure that the person providing Enhanced Supervision is aware of and understands the level of supervision they are to provide and the behaviours which are causing concern.

When providing supervision within a supervised bay, or supervision at level 3 or 4, the person providing the supervision must be informed of the mitigation in place to replace them should they have to leave the area for any reason; for example breaks or to provide urgent clinical care elsewhere.

Staff members providing Enhanced Supervision must ensure that they have completed the Mandatory Training required to provide that supervision. They must ensure they aware of the level of Supervision they are being asked to provide and, for supervised bays and levels 3 and 4 supervision, the mitigation in place should they need to leave the area for any reason.

Staff providing Enhanced Supervision must ensure that they call for assistance should they have to leave the area for any reason. They must ensure that Supervision is provided in a supportive manner and wherever possible provide positive interaction.

Staff providing Enhanced observations are responsible for completing the Enhanced Supervision paperwork and providing a summary of the behaviours of the patient during their period of supervision. This information will be used to support decisions regarding continuing or reducing the level of supervision required.

All Employees have an individual responsibility and accountability in the provision of safe and competent practice and are expected to adhere to Trust policies and follow the guidelines to prevent risks to themselves and others.
All healthcare providers must ensure that there are systems in place to protect the safety and wellbeing of patients in their care.
Staff providing enhanced supervision should be trained and competent in: Essential:
Falls Prevention and Management Training Desirable:
Experience of working with people showing challenging behaviours
Providing activities to distract from risky behaviours and enrich patient experience

*If presenting with a new onset of challenging or risky behaviours and/or risk all possible organic reasons for their behaviours should be assessed and optimally managed (for example pain, constipation, urinary retention).*

Requirements for the provision of Enhanced levels of Supervision: The patient must have been found to lack capacity and is the subject of an authorised Deprivation of Liberties or if the patients behaviour changes abruptly and before such authorisation can be sought “staff can act reasonably to get beyond the point of crisis” and authorisation may then be applied for if there is the expectation that the patient may require continuing control or supervision AND The patient is exhibiting behaviours which may lead to harm to themselves or others which may best be mitigated through enhanced levels of non-clinical supervision
6.3.1 Enhanced Supervision assessment must be completed and the level of Enhanced Supervision agreed upon
6.3.2 If the level of supervision can be provided from the ward staffing this should be commenced, otherwise refer to the escalation/de-escalation process (Appendix 1)
6.3.3 Staff providing Enhanced Supervision must be fully briefed on the level of supervision they are being asked to provide and the nature of the behaviours of concern.
6.3.4 Staff working within a Supervised bay must ensure that there is cover should they be called upon to leave the bay for any reason; for example to get equipment or to go on a break.
6.3.5 Judgement must be made in individual circumstances as to whether it is safe to provide care behind curtains within the bay which would restrict visibility.
6.3.6 Clear plans must be in place for covering staff providing level 3-4 Supervision if they are required to step away for any reason (for example, breaks or urgent care provision requirements)

6.3.7 In instances where enhanced supervision is being provided to mitigate falls risk it is recognised that this may only be possible if the patient can be effectively dissuaded or distracted from risky behaviour.
6.3.8 There may be instances whereby close physical supervision may increase patient agitation and escalate behaviours. In these instances supervision may have to be given at a distance.
6.3.9 If the patient begins to fall, staff are limited in their ability to intervene as to do so may increase the risk of harm patients of themselves. Please refer to the Moving and Handling Policy.
6.4.1 Level 3 and 4: documentation/communication once per hour by the agreed member of staff summarising the patients behaviours and engagement with others
6.4.2 Level 2: Observations must be recorded each time the patient is checked upon by the agreed member of staff
6.4.4 The level of supervision required must be clearly documented and communicated at handover to all relevant staff
6.5.1 Minimum of 24 hourly unless the risks require an escalation or de-escalation in real time

6.5.2 If the patient presents a significant sustained physical risk to themselves or those around them (Staff, visitors or other patients) refer to the Management of Violence and Aggression Policy or equivalent.
